The order of a group $G$, denoted as ord $G$, is defined as the number of elements in $G$ if $G$ is finite. If $G$ is infinite, its order is said to be infinite.

An integral domain $R$ satisfying the conditions that every element $a \in R-\left(R^{*} \cup\{0\}\right)$ can be uniquely written, up to associatedness and order, as a product of irreducible elements, and every element $a \in R-\left(R^{*} \cup\{0\}\right)$ is a product of prime elements. An element of a unique factorization domain is irreducible if and only if it is prime.

Does the concept of a/an Order of a group need to be defined for a definition of a/an Factorial ring/unique factorization domain to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of a Factorial ring or unique factorization domain (UFD) pertains to the structure and properties of elements within an integral domain, specifically focusing on the factorization of elements into irreducibles or primes. This concept is purely algebraic and pertains to ring theory, particularly the study of how elements within a ring can be broken down into simpler, indivisible components.

On the other hand, the concept of the Order of a group relates to group theory, which is a different branch of abstract algebra. It deals with the properties and structure of groups, specifically the total number of elements in a group, whether finite or infinite.

There is no direct or necessary connection between the order of a group and the properties of a factorial ring or UFD. The definition and understanding of a UFD do not rely on or require knowledge of group theory or the concept of the order of a group. The two concepts operate independently within their respective areas of algebra.
